subject: Re: [junit] How JUnit runs test class
msgSnippet: Hi David, ... Agreed, but how about people who are using JUnit to do functional testing? What do you tell them?  Use TestNG?  :-) Requiring expensive immutable
messageBody:
Hi David,

On 12/22/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
>
> > Sharing expensive immutable state in the same test class is a totally
> > harmless and extremely common scenario that I wish JUnit made easier to
> > implement (i.e. no statics and no special runner).
>
> Requiring expensive immutable state in a unit test is harmful to unit
> design. (In my opinion, not thinking about unit tests and system
> tests as different things is harmful to unit and system design.)


Agreed, but how about people who are using JUnit to do functional testing?
What do you tell them? Use TestNG? :-)

Requiring expensive immutable state in functional or system tests
> happens. In these cases, I think that adding
> @RunWith(OneInstance.class) to the top of a class to mark it as
> running differently is pretty easy. Perhaps someone would like to
> suggest that this Runner should ship along with JUnit. In this case,
> the standard procedure is to open a Feature Request on SourceForge.
>
> Here's the code sample. The code for OneInstance was in my last
> e-mail. Only one instance of HumongousDataStructure is constructed.


Yes, and you are still using a static variable for this example:

public class ConstructOnceTest {
public static class HumongousDataStructure {
static int numConstructed = 0;

How would you do this without a static?

--
Cédric
